column4: Permissions Question - For a user to be able to read-only, when it comes to directories, that user must ALSO have execute permissions on that folder to actually open it and read what's inside - correct?
is this true for any OS, such as windows, etc?
That I am not sure. But under Ubuntu and RHEL it is.
thanks. I'll ask in windows to see. Pretty sure it is but I'm kinda curious. :P
Type `service` in a terminal then do a quick double tap of the TAB key, it will list all services, is Samba there?
I ran service --status-all, and I did not see "samba" in the list. I saw "smbd" but thats the closest thing I found.
samba is installed tho. apt-get install samba = 0 upgraded, 0 newly installed, 0 to remove.
not sure. I kind of doubt it tho the way its acting.
just sorta frustrating, since I rely on samba heavily and just upgraded to 10.04
I have samba installed as well and running `sudo restart smbd` I got a service restart, however using `samba` did not work.
smbd start/running, process 2850 That is my output, you do not see any of that?
